tossups.question: This leader’s attempt to carve out a separate empire failed when the French withdrew their support to focus on the Rhine Crisis. The Treaty of Balta Liman sought to undermine this leader’s economic monopolies. This leader faced an alliance formed by the Treaty of Unkiar Skelessi after this ruler’s forces were victorious at the Battle of Konya. This ruler’s forces won a victory at the Battle of Nizib during a defense of Syria that ignited the (*) “Oriental Crisis.” A fleet led by this leader’s son lost a battle against Admiral Edward Codrington that led to Greek independence. This person’s fleet lost the Battle of Navarino under his son, Ibrahim Pasha. This was the first person to call himself Khedive, and he came to power by massacring the Mamluks in a citadel. For 10 points, name this ethnic Albanian who was the Ottoman viceroy of Egypt.
tossups.answer: Muhammad Ali Pasha [or Mehmet Ali Pasha]

tossups.question: In one story, this deity carried off a lover and granted her dominion over flowers after diverting his brother towards carrying off Oreithyia instead. During Patroclus’s funeral rites, Iris goes to this deity’s house to deliver Achilles’ request that this deity and his brother light the funeral pyre. This deity mated with the harpy Podarge to father the immortal (*) horses Xanthus and Balius, and he carried Psyche to Eros’s palace. This deity is often considered the most gentle of the Anemoi, and was associated with the onset of spring. Along with Poseidon and Thetis, the Argonauts made sacrifices to this deity to ensure a successful voyage. This deity flew into a jealous rage and caused a discus thrown by Apollo to hit their beloved, Hyacinthus. For 10 points, name this Greek god of the west wind, brother of Notus, Eurus, and Boreas.

A man in this novel compliments a woman’s body by saying he’d like to see it on the dissecting table, and later criticizes sayings that “turn the commonplace upside down.” His family’s servant pretends to run into him to bring him home to his parents, who unsuccessfully try not to fuss over him. This novel ends with a description of two people visiting the one untouched grave in a dirty cemetery. A character in this novel gives a ring with a sphinx on it to the tormented socialite Princess R. That fancily-dressed man, (*) Pavel, later duels a man who kissed his brother Nikolai’s servant and eventual wife, Fenichka. This novel’s main character collects frogs, dies due to his autopsy of a typhus-infested corpse, falls in love with Anna Odintsova, and clashes with the views of the elder Kirsanov. For 10 points, name this novel about the nihilist Bazarov by Ivan Turgenev.
tossups.answer: Fathers and Sons [accept Fathers and Children or Ottsy i deti]

tossups.question: Adding terms governing this process due to the Bloch equation gives the Bloch-Torrey equation. An “apparent” coefficient governing this process is measured in a method in which each voxel is assigned a rate and direction; that method is used in tractography. In gases, this process’s coefficient is equal to one-third times mean free path times mean thermal speed, and a law driven by this process sets a property’s time derivative linearly proportional to its second spatial derivative. The (*) Einstein-Smoluchowski relation finds this process’s namesake constant proportional to mobility, Boltzmann’s constant, and temperature. The flux due to this process is proportional to the concentration gradient, as stated in Fick’s Laws. For 10 points, name this process where particles move from areas of high to low concentration.

Nancy Eisenberg opposed this thinker by studying “prosocial” acts and discriminating between “hedonistic” and “pragmatic” non-altruism, while Elliot Turiel opposed him by separating out the effect of convention in his “social domain theory.” This man worked to help high schoolers form “just communities” and included figures like Judy, who secretly buys concert tickets, in one series of case studies. He was criticized for using all-male samples in the work In a Different Voice by Carol (*) Gilligan, who criticized his study asking about Heinz stealing medicine for his sick wife. That story is key to one of this man’s theories, which states that people’s ethical standards change from obedience to conformity to universal human ethics in pre- and post-conventional levels. For 10 points, name this psychologist with a six-stage theory of moral development.

In this film, a man declares “It is an illusion!” and disappears into a cloud of blue smoke, leaving a stage empty except for a glistening blue microphone. This film opens with shots of couples dancing the jitterbug projected against a solid purple background. In this film, a woman lip syncs to a Spanish version of Roy Orbison’s “Crying” in a red-covered nightclub that looks like a retro theater, the (*) Club Silencio. A director in this film played by Justin Theroux is forced to cast a mobster’s girlfriend as the title character of his movie, The Sylvia North Story. The main characters of this film appear to switch personalities after one of them opens a mysterious blue box. This film begins with a woman fleeing a car crash with amnesia, telling a Naomi Watts-played character that her name is “Rita.” For 10 points, name this David Lynch film titled for a street in Los Angeles.

An episode of this TV show opens with a CGI tracking shot in which the camera emerges out of a microphone into a Stasi interrogation room. A character on this show reads a sci-fi book about a robot, Minsky, who wanders across the universe muttering the phrase “I can help!” Another character on this show kills a fleeing man by dropping an AC unit on his head. The statement (*) “THIS IS A TRUE STORY” appears at the beginning of each episode of this show, whose characters include a villainous Englishman with rotten teeth named V. M. Varga. The most recent season of this show starred Carrie Coons as Sheriff Gloria Burgle and Ewan McGregor in a double role as Ray and Emmit Stussy, brothers feuding over a rare stamp collection. For 10 points, name this FX anthology series based on a Coen brothers film where Steve Buscemi is put in a woodchipper.

Severe necrotic lesions caused by this disease are called lues maligna. The Wasserman test for this disease has largely been replaced by the reactive-plasma reagin and VDRL tests. Clutton’s joints and sabre shins are manifestations of one form of this disease, which can also manifest as interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson’s teeth, and deafness in its congenital form. The causative agent of this disease shares a genus with the causative agents of bejel, pinta, (*) and yaws. This disease is often diagnosed using dark-field microscopy or by detecting FTA antibodies. Its primary form is characterized by painful ulcerating lesions called chancres, and its tertiary form can cause insanity. For 10 points, name this sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema pallidum.

This kingdom gained religious freedom in the Nvarsak Treaty 30 years after a sparapet of the Mamikonian family led it in the Battle of Avarayr. The patron saint of this home of Vardan was imprisoned for 14 years at Khor Virap monastery. This kingdom’s greatest ruler was a hostage for the first 45 years of his life before trading “seventy valleys” in Atropatene for his freedom. That ruler of this kingdom allied with a ruler to the west by marrying that person’s daughter, Cleopatra, but was attacked by (*) Lucullus in return. This kingdom became the first to make Christianity the official religion under Tiridates III due to the efforts of St. Gregory the Illuminator. This kingdom was ruled by members of the Artaxiad dynasty and aided the revolt of Mithridates VI. For 10 points, give this classical kingdom ruled by Tigranes the Great which had a capital near Mount Ararat.

This author created a character who didn’t wear her wedding ring for two years after her husband got drunk and threw his ring into a peach orchard; she later reunites with her cheating husband, but the two are forced to move after Fat Linda comes home. The narrator of a story by this author tells a truck driver “I want to smother” while feeling him leer at her through a car window. In that story by this author, Claire is overcome with fear and attends the funeral of the girl her husband found dead in a (*) river. This author of “So Much Water So Close to Home” wrote about Frank Martin’s “drying-out facility” in “Where I’m Calling From” and about two couples who drink gin around an ice bucket while discussing Mel’s ex-wife Marjorie and Terri’s abusive ex Ed, who shot himself. For 10 points, name this author of “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love.”

In this city, hundreds of nobles with concealed knives sought to protect their monarch but were disarmed by troops in the Day of Daggers. In this city, troops fired upon people signing a petition circulated by the Cordeliers Club on the non-Roman Field of Mars. The killing of prisoners in this city’s jails by mobs was dubbed the “September Massacres.” An insurrection in this city was quelled by a rising general in a “whiff of grapeshot.” Bernard Launay and Mayor (*) Flesselles were killed in one event in this city and had their heads put on pikes; the latter was killed outside the city hall, which is called the Hotel de Ville. The urban lower class of this city wore distinctive trousers, leading them to be called the sans-culottes. For 10 points, name this city home to a notorious prison called the Bastille.

Although this figure is not the Virgin Mary, she is syncretized with the Fujianese sea-goddess Mazu. This figure made a disabled boy hobble off a cliff as a test of devotion. In some art, this figure is depicted flanked by two child disciples, with a white cockatoo, or holding a willow branch. In one story, this figure’s father tried to horribly bully her into a marriage, but she later sacrificed her (*) eyes and arms to heal him. Supplication to a male version of this deity is described in a late chapter of the Lotus Sutra. The Amitabha Buddha gave this deity extra limbs so that she could hear and reach those who were suffering. For 10 points, name this eleven-headed, thousand-armed androgynous deity of compassion.

IDF general Aviv Kochavi uses a strain of this school of thought to help troops ‘walk through walls.’ A thinker in this school used Carl Schmitt’s work to develop a form of “pluralist agonism” in The Democratic Paradox. Discussion of “the double of abstraction,” couched as a reference to a famous line from this school of thought, opens a work in this vein that describes (*) struggle between generators of IP and the possessing group. Mouffe and Wark are a pair of thinkers in this tradition which also has an analytical branch, exemplified by the author of “A Defence” of its namesake’s Theory of History. Gerry Cohen is among thinkers in this school who do not take a Maoist or Leninist approach. For 10 points, name this school of political thought named for the author of Das Kapital.

In a book subtitled The Dream of America from [this city] to Now, Peter Hales argues that media depictions of an event in this city created a new type of “sublime” in American popular culture. William Shawn devoted an entire issue of the New Yorker to an account of an event in this city featuring the Jesuit Father Kleinsorge. Norman Cousins helped 25 of this city’s “keloid girls” travel to America to receive surgery. This city was likely chosen as the first (*) target of a military operation because Henry Stimson wanted to spare the city where he had his honeymoon. John Hersey wrote a book about an attack on this city that resulted in the scrapping of Operation Downfall. Colonel Paul Tibbets dropped a device called “Little Boy” on this city out of the Enola Gay. For 10 points, what Japanese city was destroyed by an atomic bomb three days before a similar raid on Nagasaki?
tossups.answer: Hiroshima [do NOT accept or prompt on “Nagasaki”; Peter Hales’ book is called Outside the Gates of Eden: The Dream of America from Hiroshima to Now]

tossups.question: For a monatomic ideal gas, the amount of these constructs is proportional to the internal energy raised to the power of three-halves times the particle number. In the microcanonical ensemble, the expression for the number of these constructs must be corrected by dividing by the factorial of the particle number in correct Boltzmann (*) counting. The derivative of the amount of these constructs with respect to the energy equals the inverse temperature. Given a sufficiently long period of time, a system will visit all of these configurations with equal probability according to the ergodic hypothesis. Entropy is equal to Boltzmann’s constant times the logarithm of the number of these objects. For 10 points, name these microscopic configurations that a thermodynamic system can occupy.

Hourticq argued that this painting was an illustration of Colonna’s novel Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, but this was supplanted by Panofsky’s and Freyhan’s arguments for a dualistic philosophical interpretation. A jet of water spouts out of a frieze showing a horse and a man being whipped in this work. Some men chasing rabbits on horseback and a shepherd with a flock are on this painting’s top right, underneath a burning (*) jar of incense held by a figure with a red robe. This painting’s main figures sit near an ornate plate on a sarcophagus of water, into which a child sitting between them dips his hand. This painting was commissioned for Nicolo Aurelio’s wedding to Laura Bagarotto. A woman clothed in a puffy white dress sits on the left, contrasted with a nude woman on the right. For 10 points, name this Titian painting which contrasts two aspects of Venus.
tossups.answer: Sacred and Profane Love [or Amor Sacro e Amor Profano]

tossups.question: Although it is not a string quartet, Bartok’s early work of this type is in two movements thought to represent himself and Stefi Geyer. The premiere of one work of this type was ruined when Victor Novacek was asked to play instead of the dedicatee Willy Burmester; while describing that work, Donald Tovey famously said the final movement sounded like a (*) “polonaise for polar bears.” Another one of these works was originally meant to be four movements, but the composer replaced the planned Scherzo with a “feeble Adagio.” The soloist’s entrance is accompanied by timpani in that D major work, a clear homage to an earlier work by Beethoven in the same key and genre. For 10 points, name these works for a high-pitched string instrument and orchestra.

This author declared, “I don’t believe in ... aesthetics. As a general rule, they are no more than useless abstractions” in the preface to a poetry collection. He wrote about a dying man who has been in heaven “every second since the moment of his death.” “The End and the Beginning” appears in a collection where Abel asks Cain, “Was it you that killed me, or did I kill you?” This author of In Praise of Darkness dedicated to H.P. Lovecraft a story in which home renovations designed by Alexander Muir cause supernatural events. “There (*) Are More Things” appears in a collection by this author whose title story features a book in an unknown language with no beginning or end. In a story by this author, Carlos Daneiri’s cellar contains a point from which all places are visible. For 10 points, name this author of The Book of Sand and “The Aleph.”

This is the only dimension for which the smooth Poincare conjecture has not been resolved and the only dimension for which R to the n has an exotic smooth structure. In this many dimensions, isomorphisms of piecewise linear and smooth manifolds are the same, but different from isomorphisms of topological manifolds. The Hopf fibration is a map from a sphere in this many dimensions to a sphere in one fewer dimensions. This is the dimension of an algebra denoted (*) H for its discoverer, Hamilton. The volume of a unit sphere in this many dimensions is pi squared over two. This is the minimum number of dimensions in which the Klein bottle can be embedded with no self-intersections. Minkowski space has this many dimensions since it models spacetime. For 10 points, give the number of dimensions in a tesseract.

One poem named after this city describes “the Zion of the water bead” and “the synagogue of the ear of corn.” That poem refuses to “blaspheme … with any further elegy of innocence and youth.” One poem named after this city remarks how a “Soldier’s sigh runs in blood down palace walls” before describing the cursing of young prostitutes. “After the first death, there is no other” ends a poem named after the (*) “Refusal to Mourn the Death, by Fire, of a Child in” this place. Another poem named after this city notes “marks of weakness, marks of woe” and “mind-forged manacles.” This city is compared to a “fen of stagnant waters” in a poem that apostrophizes “Milton! Thou shouldst be living at this hour.” For 10 points, name this city, namesake of a William Wordsworth poem named after it in 1802 and a William Blake poem describing “the chartered Thames.”

bonuses.leadin: Emily Whitehead was the first patient to successfully receive this therapy. For 10 points each:
answers: CAR T-Cell Therapy [or Chimeric Antigen Receptor T-Cell Therapy]
parts: Name this cancer therapy in which T-Cells are modified to target tumor specific antigens such as CD19 by expressing different T-cell receptors. The FDA recently approved its use for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Ordinarily, T cell receptors are produced in the body through this error prone process in which genetic fragments are randomly rearranged and joined together through non-homologous end joining.

V(D)J recombination is also used to produce the variable domain of this class of glycoproteins that possess a heavy chain region and a light chain region. These proteins bind to antigens during an immune response.

bonuses.leadin: This man died in 1918 during a routine training flight, when his airplane went into a nosedive and his body fell out of the cockpit. For 10 points each:
answers: Tammany Hall [or Society of St. Tammany; or Sons of St. Tammany; or the Columbian Order; or the Tammany Society]
Thomas E. Dewey [or Thomas Edmund Dewey]
parts: Name this “Boy Mayor of New York” who lost the 1918 mayoral election to John Francis Hylan. His grandfather of the same name was a Young Ireland activist who urged Irish-Americans to support the Confederacy.
John Purroy Mitchel gained his reputation as a reformer by taking on this political machine. In the 19th century, this super-corrupt New York organization was controlled by William “Boss” Tweed.

This New York politician took on Tammany Hall while serving as Fiorello La Guardia’s special prosecutor in the 1930s. Also known for his investigation of Dutch Schultz, he later ran for office with running mate Earl Warren..

bonuses.leadin: Jaegwon Kim’s response to this paper is titled, “What is [its title concept]?” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this paper by W.V.O. Quine which calls for a turn away from the traditional “armchair” discussions of its title discipline.
Quine argued that epistemology should focus on how people attain knowledge, not what knowledge is. This author of Phaedo and Meno defined knowledge as “justified true belief” in his Theaetetus.

Quine wanted to stay away from “folk psychology,” which contains concepts that do not actually exist according to this view. Daniel Dennett expresses a strong form of this view that denies qualia concepts like pain.

bonuses.leadin: The title character of this book starts out “completely unremarkable in any way” but slowly goes insane after dreaming about animals being slaughtered. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Han Kang novel, in which Yeong-hye Cheong’s family has an “intervention” after she starts the title practice. She has sex with a man with flowers painted on his body and becomes gradually more plant-like.
Han Kang is from this country, home to the author of “Azalea,” Kim Sowol. This country’s poet Ko Un wrote about his visit to its totalitarian neighbor in his collection North and South.
In this Kenzaburo Oe novel, the Korean “Emperor” is a grocery store owner against whom Takashi organizes a group of football-playing children. Taskashi then rather memorably kills himself.

bonuses.leadin: When the index of one of these processes is 1, it is isothermal given a few other assumptions. For 10 points each:
answers: isochoric process [prompt on anything mentioning constant volume]
parts: Name this kind of process, in which pressure times volume raised to the nth power is held constant. The n in the previous statement is the namesake index of this process.
When this law applies to a polytropic process, the ratio of energy transfer as heat and energy transfer as work for each step is constant. This law is simply stated as PV equals n R T.
A polytropic process with index infinity is this kind of process, which also appears as a vertical line in a PV diagram.

bonuses.leadin: This politician represented Britain at the Congress of Berlin. For 10 points each:
answers: Chancellor of the Exchequer [or Chancellor and the Under-Treasurer of Her Majesty’s Exchequer; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this Conservative politician and opponent of William Gladstone who is the only Jew to have become Prime Minister.
Disraeli held this position during the two ministries of Lord Derby. The holder of this office gives the Mansion House speech every June, and their official residence is 11 Downing Street.
After becoming Prime Minister, Disraeli remarked that he had climbed to the top of this two word object, which may refer to the difficulty of a Jew reaching high office.

bonuses.leadin: This word names a set of orchestral works by Ralph Vaughan Williams based on folk songs of Norfolk County. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this word that accompanies the words “in Blue” and “in Rivets” in the titles of popular works by George Gershwin. Rachmaninov wrote a set of these works on a “theme by Paganini.”
This virtuoso violinist was inspired by lautareasca music to compose his Romanian Rhapsodies. He also collaborated with Merri Franquin to create a popular work for trumpet and piano called Legende.
This German composer composed Alto Rhapsody based on a Goethe poem about a lost soul in a wasteland.

bonuses.leadin: In The Toast series “Two Monks” “inventing” [this place’s] art, Monk #2 tells Monk #1 that people relaxing “stand in a straight line and look straight ahead” and “nobody can bend at the waist ever.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this empire, which produced works of art such as the Hagia Sophia and many gold-leaf-backed icons depicting flat, stylized religious figures.
This Byzantine Romanos-group ivory triptych presents a Deesis scene of Christ on a throne with a book, while the back shows a Garden of Eden with two cypresses leaning towards a cross.
This Sienese artist was influenced by Byzantine styles to create his Maesta and his Rucellai Madonna, both of which show a Virgin and child surrounded by angels and saints.

bonuses.leadin: This poet “stands confirm’d in full stupidity,” and “never deviates into sense.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “True-blue Protestant poet,” who is satirized in a mock-heroic work beginning “All human things are subject to decay” in which he solemnly swears to remain dull and is crowned by the king Nonsense.
In addition to mocking Shadwell in “MacFlecknoe,” this poet wrote about Palmyra and Leonidas in Marriage a la Mode and described his conversion to Catholicism in “The Hind and the Panther.”
Dryden satirized the rebellion of the Earl of Shaftsbury and the Duke of Monmouth, represented as the two title Biblical characters rebelling against David in this monarchic poem.

bonuses.leadin: This architect designed the walnut-panelled gallery of Chris Ofili’s work Upper Room, which was controversially purchased by the Tate in 2005. For 10 points each:
answers: National Museum of African American History and Culture (be kind and accept any reasonable answer suggesting a museum or Smithsonian institute of African American History)
parts: Name this British-Ghanaian architect who created the light installation Your black horizon at the Venice Biennale and more recently designed the Nobel Peace Centre in Oslo.

Adjaye was the lead designer of this project, the latest Smithsonian museum. It is located on the National Mall and takes the rough form of an inverted ziggurat that supposedly visually references a Yoruban crown.
That museum was constructed on a plot of land set aside for a museum in this man’s 1791 plan for Washington, D.C.

bonuses.leadin: People who can enter this state more easily are said to have an autotelic personality. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this state described by Mihaly Csíkszentmihályi (me-hi chick-sent-me-hi), in which a person is fully immersed in and enjoying a challenging activity.

This greedy algorithm computes the maximum flow in a network by sending the maximum possible flow along an augmenting path with nonzero capacity from source to sink, then finding maximum flow on the residual graph.
This type of chaotic flow, often contrasted with laminar flow, occurs at high Reynolds numbers when inertial forces overcome viscous forces.

bonuses.leadin: In response to his hoax, this man wrote “Anyone who believes that the laws of physics are mere social conventions is invited to try transgressing those conventions from the windows of my apartment.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this physicist who published the paper “Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity” before revealing that it was complete nonsense.
A.D. Harvey falsified a newly-discovered interview between this author of A Tale of Two Cities and Dostoyevsky, before it was uncovered as part of a fake network of arguing scholars.
In another academic hoax, the 18th-century professor James MacPherson claimed to have discovered poems like Fingal written by this Celtic hero, a son of Finn MacCool, but he just wrote them himself.

bonuses.leadin: According to an equation named for this man, the sum of the electron and ion temperatures is proportional to the square of the total current. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this physicist. He also names a type of plasma pinch in which a current flowing in the plasma produces an azimuthal magnetic field which compresses it.

Z-pinches can generate poloidal magnetic fields, but these devices generate toroidal magnetic fields as well to confine plasmas in the shape of a torus. Due to their large currents, they often suffer from instabilities.
Tokamaks are considered the leading candidates for reactors which would produce energy by this process. This process combines two nuclei to form a heavier one, releasing energy in the process.

bonuses.leadin: This character claims that “you can’t be old without money” and calls her nephews and nieces “no-neck monsters.” For 10 points each:
answers: Maggie the Cat [accept Margaret Pollitt; prompt on “Pollitt”]
parts: Name this character, who locks liquor away from her alcoholic husband Brick until they conceive so they can get an inheritance from the dying Big Daddy Pollitt.
Maggie is the title Cat on a Hot Tin Roof in a play by this writer of The Glass Menagerie.

In Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Brick and Big Daddy rail against this term. Brick claims that “liquor is one way out and death’s the other” from this term, which he blames for people labeling his relationship with Skipper as gay.

bonuses.leadin: Over the course of the 19th century, European powers scrambled over each other to explore and colonize the African continent. For 10 points each:
answers: Otto von Bismarck [or Otto Eduard Leopold, Prince of Bismarck, Duke of Lauenburg]
parts: This big game hunter founded a hunting association called the Shikar Club. This person fought under Cecil Rhodes during the Matabele war and names an elite unit that used terror tactics during the Second Chimurenga.
This German Chancellor sought to create European spheres of influence by hosting the Berlin Conference. This person gave the Blood and Iron speech to advocate for German unification.

The Berlin Conference helped allow Germany to consolidate control over a colony in Southwest Africa where they subjected this ethnic group, the Nama, and the San people to a genocide under general Lothar von Trotha.

bonuses.leadin: You are an ancient Egyptian who just died. Answer some questions about things that might happen to you, for 10 points each:
parts: Based on the Egyptian Book of the Dead, you believe your soul will be led into the presence of this god of the afterlife. Set tricked him into climbing into a coffin and chopped him up, but his wife Iris put him back together.

The Book of the Dead says that your soul will be weighed against the goddess Ma'at, represented by one of these things. If the scales don’t balance because your soul is too impure, Ammit the Devourer eats your heart.
You believe that this part of the soul will survive your death and go to the afterworld, unlike the ka, which is separated from your body at death, and the ba, which moves between life and death.

bonuses.leadin: Despite his wife’s warning to “Have nothing to do with that righteous man,” this person went on to condemn said righteous man to death. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Roman prefect responsible for the trial and crucifixion of Jesus. His wife had a dream that told her that Jesus was innocent, but her husband failed to heed her warning.
In Genesis, Abimelech takes this beautiful woman into his harem but receives a dream from God warning him not to touch her, since she’s already married.

After God comes to him in a dream, Jacob awakes and says “This can be but the house of God, and this is the gate of the heavens.” He then sets up a pillar, anoints it with oil, and gives it this name.

bonuses.leadin: Irom Sharmila ended what is generally considered the longest ever one of these events in 2016. For 10 points each:
answers: hunger strikes [prompt on “fasting” or descriptive answers like “refusing to eat”]
parts: Name this action which also caused the death of Potti Sreeramulu, who sought the creation of Andhra State for the Telugu people.
This other Indian leader used hunger strikes to great effect as part of his doctrine of satyagraha and successfully achieved Indian independence from Britain.

Jatin Das and a man with this last name went on hunger strike while jailed for allegedly killing police officers. Two bodyguards with this last name assassinated Indira Gandhi after she ordered an attack on the Golden Temple.

bonuses.leadin: A 1971 paper by Karp listed 21 problems with this property. For 10 points each:
answers: NP-complete [prompt on NP or NP-hard; accept P or NP only if they provide a correct proof that P=NP]
parts: Name this property of certain computational problems which means that they can be solved in polynomial time by a non-deterministic Turing machine.

One of Karp’s original NP-complete problems was this problem of determining whether, for a given graph, there is a collection of vertices such that every edge connects to at least one vertex in the collection.
The class NP is often contrasted with this other complexity class. This complexity class contains problems that can be solved in polynomial time by a Turing machine.

bonuses.leadin: A gate in this work bears an inscription beginning “I am the way into the city of woe, I am the way into eternal pain.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work, whose narrator is “midway in the journey of our life” when he evades a leopard, a lion, and a she-wolf in a forest.
The Inferno was written as part of the Divine Comedy by this Italian poet, who depicted himself going to Paradise to see his love Beatrice.
These people are barked at by Cerberus in the third circle of hell. Dante meets one of these people, Ciacco, who is forced to lie flattened by the rain.
